Make A Pit Stop In Reston For Bike To Work Day On May 20
Celebrate Bike to Work Day May 20 with pit stops in and around the Reston. National Bike Week happens to be this week.
Michael O'Connell,
Patch Staff
Posted Wed, May 18, 2022 at 12:28 pm ET
Celebrate Bike to Work Day May 20 with pit stops in and around Reston. National Bike Week happens to be this week. (Shutterstock)

RESTON, VA â€” National Bike Week happens to be this week with the 21st anniversary of Bike to Work Day in the National Capital Region falling on May 20.

Reston will be among the participating locations, with nearly 100 pit stops planned around the DC region as commuters head to or from work. Pit stops will offer T-shirts to the first 15,000 who register and show up, as well as other activities. Free snacks and drinks, swag and bicycling information will be offered at most pit stops, and raffle prizes will be offered at some pit stops. Many pit stops are in the morning, but a handful are planned in the afternoon.

Participants must register at biketoworkmetrodc.org to be eligible for the free T-shirt. When registering, participants will choose one pit stop.

In Reston, bicyclists can head to a pit stop just off the Washington & Old Dominion Trail at The Bike Lane, 11150 Sunset Hills Reston, VA, 7 a.m.-9 a.m.

Here are other nearby pit stops:


Find out what's happening in Restonwith free, real-time updates from Patch.
Subscribe
Herndon Town Hall Green, W&OD Trail at the intersection of Lynn and Elden streets, 5:30 a.m.-10 a.m.
Oak Marr RECenter, 3200 Jermantown Road, Oakton, VA, 6:30 a.m.-9 a.m.
Vienna Town Green, W&OD Trail, 144 Maple Avenue East, Vienna, VA, 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 a.m.
Tysons Corner Center (in front of Capital Grille), 1861 International Drive, McLean, VA, 6:30 a.m.-10 a.m.
The MITRE Corporation, 7596 Colshire Drive, Tysons, VA, 6:30 a.m.-9 a.m.
Fairfax County Government Center, 12000 Government Center Pkwy, Fairfax, VA, 6:30 a.m.-9 a.m.
Fair Lakes Center (in front of Noodles & Co.), 12961 Fair Lakes Center Drive, Fairfax, VA, 6 a.m.-9 a.m.
Old Town Square, North Street & Old Lee Highway, Fairfax, VA, 6 a.m.-9 a.m.
West End Park, W&OD Trail & Grove Ave, Falls Church, VA, 6:30 a.m.-9 a.m.
Strawberry Park, 2910 District Avenue, Fairfax, VA, 4 p.m.-6:30 p.m.

The event is sponsored by Commuter Connections and the Washington Area Bicyclist Association.


"Bike to Work Day gives us the opportunity to jumpstart our day with a fun, healthy commuting option, all while reducing traffic congestion on roadways that are getting crowded once again," said Nicholas Ramfos, Commuter Connections director, in a news release.

Don't have a bike? Capital Bikeshare will be offering non-members free unlimited rides up to 45 minutes per trip on standard bikes Friday. Electric bikes will be available for $0.10 per minute with no unlock fee. To find station locations, visit capitalbikeshare.com.
To see other pit stops or register, visit www.biketoworkmetrodc.org.

Alexandria Students Place Second, Win $15K in Scholarship Prizes at New York Finals of M3 Challenge
 Kevin Dauray 
Send an email
May 1, 2024
 1 minute read
Facebook
 
Twitter
 
LinkedIn
 
Tumblr
 
Pinterest

Messenger
 
Share via Email
 
Print
Thomas Jefferson High School M3 Challenge Finalists, from the left, Om Gole, Laura Zhang, Rishabh Prabhu, Victoria Zhang (Photo: M3 Challenge)

ALEXANDRIA, VA-Three weeks ago, The Zebra Press reported on a group of students fromÂ  Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology (TJHS) who were selected as finalists for the Â MathWorks Math Modeling Challenge (M3 Challenge). That selection made them eligible for $20K in scholarship prizes.

In New York City on April 29, Â Rishabh Chhabra, Om Gole, Rishabh Prabhu, Laura Zhang, and Victoria Zhang placed second in the contest, taking home $15,000. The winners are from Phillips Academy, based in Andover MA.

â€œWhat sets M3 Challenge apart from other math competitions is that it uniquely requires students to use math modeling as a process to represent, analyze, make predictions and provide insight into current phenomena,â€ said Dr. Karen Bliss, Senior Manager of Education and Outreach at SIAM. â€œWe pose big problems about real issues that many students may not know much about. They need to research, quantify the parameters, organize data, and use skills theyâ€™ve learned in math class but may have never related to something real.â€

The M3 Challenge is a program of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, headquartered in Philadelphia. It is sponsored by MathWorks, and began in 2005. It highlights the importance of math in daily life.

Support Good News Journalism, Subscribe >>

The judging panel for the final included professional mathematiciains.

Thousands of students from the US and UK participate in the M3 Challenge each year. Only six percent of entrants were given scholarship prizes.

[SEE ALSO: Whatâ€™s Happening This Summer in Alexandria?]

Kevin Dauray
Kevin is Publisher's Assistant with The Zebra Press. He has been working for Alexandria's "Good News" newspaper since 2019. A graduate of George Mason University, he earned a bachelor's in English with a concentration in Creative Writing. He also studied at the Columbia School of Broadcasting and holds a master's degree in Clinical Mental Health Counseling from Marymount University. He is an alumnus of T.C. Williams High School.
